title: Trump Gives Some Federal Workers Christmas Eve Off—Though Congress Is on the Job
sub_head: Previous presidents have customarily given federal workers a half-day off on Dec. 24 when Christmas has fallen on a Friday
body:
WASHINGTON—For the third year in a row, President Trump has given employees of the executive branch of the federal government a full day off on Christmas Eve, though Congress remained on the job Thursday morning.
When Christmas has fallen on a Friday, as it does this year, presidents have customarily given federal workers a half-day off on Dec. 24, as President Obama did in 2009 and 2015 and President Clinton did in 1998, according to Government Executive, a trade publication.
The federal government observes 11 permanent holidays established by law, including Christmas, but Christmas Eve isn’t among them.
About two million people, just over 1% of the U.S. workforce, are permanently employed by the federal government outside the military and the U.S. Postal Service, according to the Brookings Institution, a nonpartisan public policy research organization. It wasn’t immediately known Thursday how many got the day off.
Some past presidents have given federal employees an extra day off when Dec. 25 falls on or near a weekend. President Bush excused federal employees from work on Christmas Eve in 2001 and 2007, when Christmas fell on a Tuesday, as it did in 2012, when Mr. Obama also called for a day off, Government Executive reported. In 2014, with Christmas on a Thursday, Mr. Obama granted workers a day off on Dec. 26.
